Bundle-ManifestVersion: 2 Bundle-Name: Barrio Interface Filter Plug-in Bundle-Version: 1.0.31 Require-Bundle: org.eclipse.ui,org.eclipse.core.runtime,nz.ac.massey.cs.barrio Eclipse-LazyStart: true Bundle-SymbolicName: nz.ac.massey.cs.barrio.interfaceFilter;singleton:=true Manifest-Version: 1.0 Bundle-Vendor: Massey University Bundle-Activator: nz.ac.nassey.cs.barrio.interfaceFilter.Activator

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
Barrio is a dependency analyzer for object-oriented programs implemented in Java. It discovers and visualizes community structures in the dependency graph which might represent opportunities to refactor the program into a more modular structure. For instance, a package containing two independent clusters could be spilt, and the new packages could be deployed in separate jar files. Barrio will also detect if there are few dependencies that destroy the modularity of programs (i.e., glue clusters together).
Barrio is design as an Eclipse plugin. Barrio has the following features:
1. Barrio can import dependency graphs stored as ODEM files (these graphs can be generated with CDA). 2. Barrio can apply filters to the graph. 3. Barrio can visualize the graph. Visualization is based on Prefuse. 4. Barrio can find clusters in the graph based on the Girvan-Newman algorithm. The Jung implementation of the algorithm is used. 5. Barrio allows users to set a separation level in order to remove edges destroying the modularity of the program. Those edges might present refactoring opportunities. 6. The discovered clusters are compared with the modular structure of the program (i.e., the use of packages and jar containers).

instructions.instruction: true

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
Barrio is a dependency analyzer for object-oriented programs implemented in Java. It discovers and visualizes community structures in the dependency graph which might represent opportunities to refactor the program into a more modular structure. For instance, a package containing two independent clusters could be spilt, and the new packages could be deployed in separate jar files. Barrio will also detect if there are few dependencies that destroy the modularity of programs (i.e., glue clusters together).
Barrio is design as an Eclipse plugin. Barrio has the following features:
1. Barrio can import dependency graphs stored as ODEM files (these graphs can be generated with CDA). 2. Barrio can apply filters to the graph. 3. Barrio can visualize the graph. Visualization is based on Prefuse. 4. Barrio can find clusters in the graph based on the Girvan-Newman algorithm. The Jung implementation of the algorithm is used. 5. Barrio allows users to set a separation level in order to remove edges destroying the modularity of the program. Those edges might present refactoring opportunities. 6. The discovered clusters are compared with the modular structure of the program (i.e., the use of packages and jar containers).

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
Barrio is a dependency analyzer for object-oriented programs implemented in Java. It discovers and visualizes community structures in the dependency graph which might represent opportunities to refactor the program into a more modular structure. For instance, a package containing two independent clusters could be spilt, and the new packages could be deployed in separate jar files. Barrio will also detect if there are few dependencies that destroy the modularity of programs (i.e., glue clusters together).
Barrio is design as an Eclipse plugin. Barrio has the following features:
1. Barrio can import dependency graphs stored as ODEM files (these graphs can be generated with CDA). 2. Barrio can apply filters to the graph. 3. Barrio can visualize the graph. Visualization is based on Prefuse. 4. Barrio can find clusters in the graph based on the Girvan-Newman algorithm. The Jung implementation of the algorithm is used. 5. Barrio allows users to set a separation level in order to remove edges destroying the modularity of the program. Those edges might present refactoring opportunities. 6. The discovered clusters are compared with the modular structure of the program (i.e., the use of packages and jar containers).

instructions.instruction: true

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
Barrio is a dependency analyzer for object-oriented programs implemented in Java. It discovers and visualizes community structures in the dependency graph which might represent opportunities to refactor the program into a more modular structure. For instance, a package containing two independent clusters could be spilt, and the new packages could be deployed in separate jar files. Barrio will also detect if there are few dependencies that destroy the modularity of programs (i.e., glue clusters together).
Barrio is design as an Eclipse plugin. Barrio has the following features:
1. Barrio can import dependency graphs stored as ODEM files (these graphs can be generated with CDA). 2. Barrio can apply filters to the graph. 3. Barrio can visualize the graph. Visualization is based on Prefuse. 4. Barrio can find clusters in the graph based on the Girvan-Newman algorithm. The Jung implementation of the algorithm is used. 5. Barrio allows users to set a separation level in order to remove edges destroying the modularity of the program. Those edges might present refactoring opportunities. 6. The discovered clusters are compared with the modular structure of the program (i.e., the use of packages and jar containers).

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
Barrio is a dependency analyzer for object-oriented programs implemented in Java. It discovers and visualizes community structures in the dependency graph which might represent opportunities to refactor the program into a more modular structure. For instance, a package containing two independent clusters could be spilt, and the new packages could be deployed in separate jar files. Barrio will also detect if there are few dependencies that destroy the modularity of programs (i.e., glue clusters together).
Barrio is design as an Eclipse plugin. Barrio has the following features:
1. Barrio can import dependency graphs stored as ODEM files (these graphs can be generated with CDA). 2. Barrio can apply filters to the graph. 3. Barrio can visualize the graph. Visualization is based on Prefuse. 4. Barrio can find clusters in the graph based on the Girvan-Newman algorithm. The Jung implementation of the algorithm is used. 5. Barrio allows users to set a separation level in order to remove edges destroying the modularity of the program. Those edges might present refactoring opportunities. 6. The discovered clusters are compared with the modular structure of the program (i.e., the use of packages and jar containers).

instructions.instruction: true

Bundle-ManifestVersion: 2 Bundle-Name: Barrio Interface Filter Plug-in Bundle-Version: 1.0.35 Require-Bundle: org.eclipse.ui,org.eclipse.core.runtime,nz.ac.massey.cs.barrio Eclipse-LazyStart: true Bundle-SymbolicName: nz.ac.massey.cs.barrio.interfaceFilter;singleton:=true Manifest-Version: 1.0 Bundle-Vendor: Massey University Bundle-Activator: nz.ac.nassey.cs.barrio.interfaceFilter.Activator

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
Barrio is a dependency analyzer for object-oriented programs implemented in Java. It discovers and visualizes community structures in the dependency graph which might represent opportunities to refactor the program into a more modular structure. For instance, a package containing two independent clusters could be spilt, and the new packages could be deployed in separate jar files. Barrio will also detect if there are few dependencies that destroy the modularity of programs (i.e., glue clusters together).
Barrio is design as an Eclipse plugin. Barrio has the following features:
1. Barrio can import dependency graphs stored as ODEM files (these graphs can be generated with CDA). 2. Barrio can apply filters to the graph. 3. Barrio can visualize the graph. Visualization is based on Prefuse. 4. Barrio can find clusters in the graph based on the Girvan-Newman algorithm. The Jung implementation of the algorithm is used. 5. Barrio allows users to set a separation level in order to remove edges destroying the modularity of the program. Those edges might present refactoring opportunities. 6. The discovered clusters are compared with the modular structure of the program (i.e., the use of packages and jar containers).

instructions.instruction: true

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
Barrio is a dependency analyzer for object-oriented programs implemented in Java. It discovers and visualizes community structures in the dependency graph which might represent opportunities to refactor the program into a more modular structure. For instance, a package containing two independent clusters could be spilt, and the new packages could be deployed in separate jar files. Barrio will also detect if there are few dependencies that destroy the modularity of programs (i.e., glue clusters together).
Barrio is design as an Eclipse plugin. Barrio has the following features:
1. Barrio can import dependency graphs stored as ODEM files (these graphs can be generated with CDA). 2. Barrio can apply filters to the graph. 3. Barrio can visualize the graph. Visualization is based on Prefuse. 4. Barrio can find clusters in the graph based on the Girvan-Newman algorithm. The Jung implementation of the algorithm is used. 5. Barrio allows users to set a separation level in order to remove edges destroying the modularity of the program. Those edges might present refactoring opportunities. 6. The discovered clusters are compared with the modular structure of the program (i.e., the use of packages and jar containers).

instructions.instruction: true

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
Barrio is a dependency analyzer for object-oriented programs implemented in Java. It discovers and visualizes community structures in the dependency graph which might represent opportunities to refactor the program into a more modular structure. For instance, a package containing two independent clusters could be spilt, and the new packages could be deployed in separate jar files. Barrio will also detect if there are few dependencies that destroy the modularity of programs (i.e., glue clusters together).
Barrio is design as an Eclipse plugin. Barrio has the following features:
1. Barrio can import dependency graphs stored as ODEM files (these graphs can be generated with CDA). 2. Barrio can apply filters to the graph. 3. Barrio can visualize the graph. Visualization is based on Prefuse. 4. Barrio can find clusters in the graph based on the Girvan-Newman algorithm. The Jung implementation of the algorithm is used. 5. Barrio allows users to set a separation level in order to remove edges destroying the modularity of the program. Those edges might present refactoring opportunities. 6. The discovered clusters are compared with the modular structure of the program (i.e., the use of packages and jar containers).

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
Barrio is a dependency analyzer for object-oriented programs implemented in Java. It discovers and visualizes community structures in the dependency graph which might represent opportunities to refactor the program into a more modular structure. For instance, a package containing two independent clusters could be spilt, and the new packages could be deployed in separate jar files. Barrio will also detect if there are few dependencies that destroy the modularity of programs (i.e., glue clusters together).
Barrio is design as an Eclipse plugin. Barrio has the following features:
1. Barrio can import dependency graphs stored as ODEM files (these graphs can be generated with CDA). 2. Barrio can apply filters to the graph. 3. Barrio can visualize the graph. Visualization is based on Prefuse. 4. Barrio can find clusters in the graph based on the Girvan-Newman algorithm. The Jung implementation of the algorithm is used. 5. Barrio allows users to set a separation level in order to remove edges destroying the modularity of the program. Those edges might present refactoring opportunities. 6. The discovered clusters are compared with the modular structure of the program (i.e., the use of packages and jar containers).

instructions.instruction: true

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
Barrio is a dependency analyzer for object-oriented programs implemented in Java. It discovers and visualizes community structures in the dependency graph which might represent opportunities to refactor the program into a more modular structure. For instance, a package containing two independent clusters could be spilt, and the new packages could be deployed in separate jar files. Barrio will also detect if there are few dependencies that destroy the modularity of programs (i.e., glue clusters together).
Barrio is design as an Eclipse plugin. Barrio has the following features:
1. Barrio can import dependency graphs stored as ODEM files (these graphs can be generated with CDA). 2. Barrio can apply filters to the graph. 3. Barrio can visualize the graph. Visualization is based on Prefuse. 4. Barrio can find clusters in the graph based on the Girvan-Newman algorithm. The Jung implementation of the algorithm is used. 5. Barrio allows users to set a separation level in order to remove edges destroying the modularity of the program. Those edges might present refactoring opportunities. 6. The discovered clusters are compared with the modular structure of the program (i.e., the use of packages and jar containers).

instructions.instruction: true

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
Barrio is a dependency analyzer for object-oriented programs implemented in Java. It discovers and visualizes community structures in the dependency graph which might represent opportunities to refactor the program into a more modular structure. For instance, a package containing two independent clusters could be spilt, and the new packages could be deployed in separate jar files. Barrio will also detect if there are few dependencies that destroy the modularity of programs (i.e., glue clusters together).
Barrio is design as an Eclipse plugin. Barrio has the following features:
1. Barrio can import dependency graphs stored as ODEM files (these graphs can be generated with CDA). 2. Barrio can apply filters to the graph. 3. Barrio can visualize the graph. Visualization is based on Prefuse. 4. Barrio can find clusters in the graph based on the Girvan-Newman algorithm. The Jung implementation of the algorithm is used. 5. Barrio allows users to set a separation level in order to remove edges destroying the modularity of the program. Those edges might present refactoring opportunities. 6. The discovered clusters are compared with the modular structure of the program (i.e., the use of packages and jar containers).

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
Barrio is a dependency analyzer for object-oriented programs implemented in Java. It discovers and visualizes community structures in the dependency graph which might represent opportunities to refactor the program into a more modular structure. For instance, a package containing two independent clusters could be spilt, and the new packages could be deployed in separate jar files. Barrio will also detect if there are few dependencies that destroy the modularity of programs (i.e., glue clusters together).
Barrio is design as an Eclipse plugin. Barrio has the following features:
1. Barrio can import dependency graphs stored as ODEM files (these graphs can be generated with CDA). 2. Barrio can apply filters to the graph. 3. Barrio can visualize the graph. Visualization is based on Prefuse. 4. Barrio can find clusters in the graph based on the Girvan-Newman algorithm. The Jung implementation of the algorithm is used. 5. Barrio allows users to set a separation level in order to remove edges destroying the modularity of the program. Those edges might present refactoring opportunities. 6. The discovered clusters are compared with the modular structure of the program (i.e., the use of packages and jar containers).

instructions.instruction: true

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
Barrio is a dependency analyzer for object-oriented programs implemented in Java. It discovers and visualizes community structures in the dependency graph which might represent opportunities to refactor the program into a more modular structure. For instance, a package containing two independent clusters could be spilt, and the new packages could be deployed in separate jar files. Barrio will also detect if there are few dependencies that destroy the modularity of programs (i.e., glue clusters together).
Barrio is design as an Eclipse plugin. Barrio has the following features:
1. Barrio can import dependency graphs stored as ODEM files (these graphs can be generated with CDA). 2. Barrio can apply filters to the graph. 3. Barrio can visualize the graph. Visualization is based on Prefuse. 4. Barrio can find clusters in the graph based on the Girvan-Newman algorithm. The Jung implementation of the algorithm is used. 5. Barrio allows users to set a separation level in order to remove edges destroying the modularity of the program. Those edges might present refactoring opportunities. 6. The discovered clusters are compared with the modular structure of the program (i.e., the use of packages and jar containers).
